sources.title: Sidewalks of London
sources.description: Title: Sidewalks of London Summary: On the sidewalks of the London theater district the buskers (street performers) earn enough coins for a cheap room. Charles, who recites dramatic monologues, sees that a young pickpocket, ... Directed by: Tim Whelan Actors: Charles Laughton, Vivien Leigh, Rex Harrison Production Company: Mayflower Pictures Corporation Release Date: 15 February 1940 (USA) Aspect Ratio: 1.37 : 1 On the sidewalks of the London theater district the buskers (street performers) earn enough coins for a cheap room. Charles, who recites dramatic monologues, sees that a young pickpocket, Libby, also has a talent for dancing and adds her to his act. Harley, the theater patron who never knew Libby took his gold cigarette case, is impressed by Libby's dancing and invites her to bring Charles and the other buskers in his group to an after-the-play party. Libby comes alone. A theatrical career is launched.

sources.title: Sidewalks of London (1938) Colorized Movie | Charles Laughton, Vivien Leigh | Subtitles
sources.description:
When VIVIEN LEIGH swings it...and CHARLES LAUGHTON sings it...WOW! 
In London's theater district, Charles, a street performer, discovers Libby, a talented pickpocket and dancer. As their act gains recognition, Libby's encounter with renowned songwriter Harley leads her to abandon Charles, propelling her to fame while Charles descends into self-destruction.

Original title: St. Martin's Lane (1938)  AKA: Sidewalks of London

Black & White version: https://youtu.be/Uudjg5pAebo

Director: Tim Whelan
Writers: Clemence Dane, Charles Laughton, Bartlett Cormack
Cast: Vivien Leigh, Charles Laughton, Rex Harrison
Genre: Colorized classics, Comedy, Drama

metadata.Plot: On the sidewalks of the London theater district the buskers (street performers) earn enough coins for a cheap room. Charles (Charles Laughton), who recites dramatic monologues, sees that a young pickpocket, Libby (Vivien Leigh), also has a talent for dancing and adds her to his act. Harley (Sir Rex Harrison), the theater patron who never knew Libby took his gold cigarette case, is impressed by Libby's dancing and invites her to bring Charles and the other buskers in his group to an after-the-play party. Libby comes alone. A theatrical career is launched.
metadata.Writer: Clemence Dane, Charles Laughton, Bartlett Cormack
